title: Hebrews Chapter 13 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Hebrews chapter 13 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Hebrews Chapter 13 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Hebrews Chapter 13.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 13:1, what should continue among brothers?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:1 instructs to let brotherly love continue, emphasizing the importance of love among believers.

questions.question: Who might some have unknowingly entertained according to Hebrews 13:2?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:2 states that by entertaining strangers, some have entertained angels unawares.

questions.question: Hebrews 13:3 instructs us to remember those who are in what condition?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:3 tells us to remember those in bonds and those suffering adversity as if suffering with them.

questions.question: What does Hebrews 13:4 say about marriage?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:4 declares that marriage is honourable in all, and the marriage bed undefiled.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 13:5, what should your conversation be without?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:5 advises that conversation be without covetousness and be content with what you have.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Hebrews 13:6: 'The Lord is my helper, and I will not fear what _____ shall do unto me.'
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:6 says we may boldly say the Lord is our helper and we will not fear what man shall do to us.

questions.question: Who does Hebrews 13:7 say we should remember?
options: Those who have the rule over you
questions.correctAnswer: Those who have the rule over you
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:7 instructs to remember those who have rule over you and have spoken the word of God.

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 13:8 states that Jesus Christ changes according to the times.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:8 states Jesus Christ is the same yesterday, today, and forever, meaning He does not change.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 13:10, who has no right to eat of the altar?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:10 explains that those who serve the tabernacle have no right to eat of the altar.

questions.question: Where were the bodies of the beasts burned according to Hebrews 13:11?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:11 says the bodies of beasts whose blood is brought into the sanctuary are burned without the camp.

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 13:12 says Jesus suffered inside the gate to sanctify the people.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:12 states Jesus suffered without the gate to sanctify the people with His own blood.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 13:14, what do believers seek?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:14 declares that believers seek a city to come, as here we have no continuing city.

questions.question: What kind of sacrifice does Hebrews 13:15 encourage believers to offer continually?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:15 encourages offering the sacrifice of praise to God continually, which is the fruit of our lips giving thanks.

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 13:16 says God is well pleased with sacrifices of doing good and sharing.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:16 states that doing good and sharing are sacrifices pleasing to God.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 13:17, why should we obey those who have rule over us?
options: Because they watch for your souls and must give account
questions.correctAnswer: Because they watch for your souls and must give account
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:17 says to obey those who rule over you because they watch for your souls and must give account.

medium.title: Hebrews Chapter 13 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Hebrews Chapter 13 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Hebrews 13:1 teach us about love among believers?
options: Love only those who love you
Ignore others to focus on yourself
Love is not important in the church
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:1 explicitly instructs believers to let brotherly love continue, emphasizing ongoing love and care among Christians, which is foundational to community life (Hebrews 13:1, 1 John 4:7-8, Romans 12:10).

questions.question: A fellow believer feels isolated and unloved. According to Hebrews 13:2, what biblical truth would you share about showing kindness to strangers?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:2 teaches that hospitality to strangers is important because some have unknowingly entertained angels, highlighting the spiritual blessing in kindness and openness (Hebrews 13:2, Matthew 25:35, Romans 12:13).

questions.question: According to Hebrews 13:3, how should Christians practically show empathy toward those suffering or imprisoned?
options: Remember them as if you are bound with them
questions.correctAnswer: Remember them as if you are bound with them
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:3 instructs believers to remember those in bonds and suffering as if they are personally involved, teaching empathy and solidarity with the afflicted (Hebrews 13:3, Galatians 6:2, Romans 12:15).

questions.question: What does Hebrews 13:4 say about the sanctity of marriage and God's judgment?
options: Marriage is honourable, but God will judge adulterers
Marriage is a private matter with no accountability
questions.correctAnswer: Marriage is honourable, but God will judge adulterers
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:4 affirms marriage as honorable and pure, while warning that God will judge immoral behavior like adultery, underscoring the importance of marital faithfulness (Hebrews 13:4, Matthew 19:6, Hebrews 10:26).

questions.question: How does Hebrews 13:5 teach contentment and trust in God?
options: Be content with what you have and trust God will never leave you
questions.correctAnswer: Be content with what you have and trust God will never leave you
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:5 encourages believers to avoid covetousness, be content with what they have, and trust in God's promise never to leave or forsake them, promoting peace and reliance on God (Hebrews 13:5, Philippians 4:11-13, Deuteronomy 31:6).

questions.question: According to Hebrews 13:6, what confidence can believers have in the Lord?
options: The Lord is my helper; I will not fear man
I must fear what others do
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord is my helper; I will not fear man
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:6 teaches believers to boldly declare that the Lord is their helper, giving them courage to not fear what people can do, highlighting trust and divine assistance (Hebrews 13:6, Psalm 118:6, Isaiah 41:10).

questions.question: What does Hebrews 13:7 encourage believers to remember about their spiritual leaders?
options: Remember their faith and imitate their conduct
questions.correctAnswer: Remember their faith and imitate their conduct
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:7 urges believers to remember those who taught God's word and to follow their faith, considering the outcome of their lives, encouraging respect and learning from godly leaders (Hebrews 13:7, 1 Thessalonians 5:12-13, Philippians 3:17).

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 13:8 teaches that Jesus Christ is unchanging and eternal.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:8 states that Jesus Christ is the same yesterday, today, and forever, affirming His eternal and unchanging nature (Hebrews 13:8, Malachi 3:6, James 1:17).

questions.question: How does Hebrews 13:9 warn believers regarding teachings and doctrines?
options: Do not be carried about with strange doctrines; establish your heart with grace
Focus on dietary rules for salvation
Ignore grace in favor of rituals
questions.correctAnswer: Do not be carried about with strange doctrines; establish your heart with grace
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:9 advises believers not to be swayed by diverse and strange doctrines but to have their hearts established by grace, not by irrelevant dietary rules (Hebrews 13:9, Colossians 2:8, Ephesians 2:8-9).

questions.question: According to Hebrews 13:15, what kind of sacrifice should believers continually offer to God?
options: The sacrifice of praise with thankful lips
questions.correctAnswer: The sacrifice of praise with thankful lips
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:15 teaches that believers should continually offer to God the sacrifice of praise, which is the fruit of lips giving thanks, emphasizing worship and gratitude (Hebrews 13:15, Psalm 50:14, Philippians 4:6).

questions.question: A believer wants to serve God well. How does Hebrews 13:16 describe what pleases God as a sacrifice?
options: Doing good and sharing with others
Only offering sacrifices in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Doing good and sharing with others
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:16 emphasizes that doing good and sharing with others is a sacrifice pleasing to God, encouraging generosity and active love (Hebrews 13:16, Acts 20:35, 1 John 3:17).

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 13:17 teaches that believers should obey and submit to their leaders because leaders are accountable to God for their souls.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:17 instructs believers to obey and submit to their leaders since they watch over souls and must give account to God, highlighting the importance of respect and cooperation within the church (Hebrews 13:17, 1 Thessalonians 5:12-13, 1 Peter 5:5).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Hebrews 13:20 refers to God as the God of _______, who brought Jesus again from the dead.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:20 calls God the God of peace who raised Jesus from the dead, emphasizing His power and tranquility that believers can rely on (Hebrews 13:20, Romans 15:33, Philippians 4:7).

questions.question: What does Hebrews 13:21 pray that God will accomplish in believers?
options: Make you perfect in every good work to do His will
Leave you to your own devices
questions.correctAnswer: Make you perfect in every good work to do His will
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:21 prays that God would perfect believers in every good work to fulfill His will, working in them what pleases Him, highlighting spiritual maturity and obedience (Hebrews 13:21, Philippians 1:6, Colossians 1:10).

questions.question: According to Hebrews 13:23, what news does the writer share about Timothy?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:23 informs the readers that Timothy has been set free, signaling good news about a fellow believer's situation and encouraging hope and restoration (Hebrews 13:23, Acts 16:37-40).

hard.title: Hebrews Chapter 13 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Hebrews Chapter 13.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 13:2, what significant event can occur when entertaining strangers?
options: Strangers become members of the church
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:2 explicitly states that by entertaining strangers, some have unknowingly entertained angels, highlighting the spiritual significance of hospitality.

questions.question: Which phrase from Hebrews 13:5 captures the promise of God's faithfulness to His people?
options: "I will never leave thee, nor forsake thee"
questions.correctAnswer: "I will never leave thee, nor forsake thee"
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:5 quotes God's promise to never abandon His people, encouraging contentment and trust in God's provision.

questions.question: Hebrews 13:4 makes a statement about marriage. What is it?
options: Marriage is honourable in all, and the bed undefiled
Marriage is a shadow of the new covenant
questions.correctAnswer: Marriage is honourable in all, and the bed undefiled
questions.explanation: The verse affirms the sanctity and honor of marriage, contrasting it with the judgment awaiting immoral behavior.

questions.question: In Hebrews 13:8, how is Jesus Christ described in relation to time?
options: The same yesterday, today, and forever
questions.correctAnswer: The same yesterday, today, and forever
questions.explanation: This verse highlights the unchanging nature of Jesus Christ, emphasizing His eternal consistency.

questions.question: Hebrews 13:10 references an altar. What typological significance does this altar hold compared to the Old Testament sacrifices?
options: It symbolizes the new covenant accessible to all believers
It represents the earthly tabernacle sacrifices
It signifies the Levitical priesthood's authority
It is a place for animal sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the new covenant accessible to all believers
questions.explanation: The altar in Hebrews 13:10 contrasts with the Old Testament tabernacle altar, signifying the new covenant established by Christ's sacrifice.

questions.question: What action does Hebrews 13:3 encourage believers to take concerning those in bonds and adversity?
options: Remember them as if bound with them and suffering as if in the body
Avoid them to preserve personal safety
questions.correctAnswer: Remember them as if bound with them and suffering as if in the body
questions.explanation: The verse calls for empathetic solidarity with those suffering or imprisoned, reflecting communal responsibility.

questions.question: Hebrews 13:14 contrasts earthly and heavenly cities. What is the key teaching about these cities?
options: We have no continuing city here, but seek one to come
The earthly city is eternal and unchanging
The earthly city is a shadow of the heavenly
questions.correctAnswer: We have no continuing city here, but seek one to come
questions.explanation: This highlights the transient nature of earthly life and the believer's hope in the eternal heavenly city.

questions.question: What is the significance of Jesus suffering 'without the gate' as mentioned in Hebrews 13:12?
options: It fulfills the typology of sin offerings burned outside the camp
It shows Jesus' rejection by Jerusalem's leaders
It symbolizes Jesus' exile from the temple
It indicates the location of His burial
questions.correctAnswer: It fulfills the typology of sin offerings burned outside the camp
questions.explanation: This reflects the Old Testament practice of burning sin offerings outside the camp, typologically fulfilled by Jesus' crucifixion outside Jerusalem.

questions.question: Hebrews 13:15 talks about offering a particular type of sacrifice continuously. What is it?
questions.explanation: The verse encourages continual praise and thanksgiving as a spiritual sacrifice to God.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 13:17, why should believers obey those who have rule over them?
options: Because they watch for your souls and must give account
Because they are appointed by government
questions.correctAnswer: Because they watch for your souls and must give account
questions.explanation: The verse emphasizes spiritual oversight and accountability of leaders for the welfare of believers.

questions.question: Hebrews 13:20 describes God as the one who brought again from the dead whom?
questions.explanation: This verse affirms the resurrection of Jesus Christ, the great shepherd of the sheep.

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 13:9 warns against being carried about with diverse and strange doctrines.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:9 cautions believers to hold firmly to grace and not be swayed by strange teachings.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Hebrews 13:6 says, 'So that we may boldly say, The Lord is my ________, and I will not fear what man shall do unto me.'
questions.explanation: The verse emphasizes confidence in God’s help, enabling believers to face fearlessly any human opposition.

questions.question: Hebrews 13:7 exhorts believers to remember their leaders. What are they specifically instructed to do?
options: Follow their faith and consider the outcome of their conduct
questions.correctAnswer: Follow their faith and consider the outcome of their conduct
questions.explanation: The verse encourages believers to imitate the faith of their leaders and reflect on how their lives conclude.

questions.question: Hebrews 13:16 highlights two actions that God is well pleased with. What are they?
options: To do good and to communicate
To give offerings and to worship
questions.correctAnswer: To do good and to communicate
questions.explanation: The verse underscores the importance of practical kindness and sharing as pleasing sacrifices to God.

theological.title: Hebrews Chapter 13 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Hebrews Chapter 13 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 13:1, what is commanded to continue among believers?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:1 commands believers to let brotherly love continue, highlighting the ongoing nature of love among Christians. This echoes Jesus' teaching in John 13:34, Paul's exhortation in Romans 12:10, and Peter's in 1 Peter 1:22.

questions.question: Hebrews 13:2 warns believers not to forget to entertain strangers because:
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:2 states that some have entertained angels without knowing it, pointing to God's sovereign use of hospitality. This aligns with Old Testament examples such as Abraham in Genesis 18:2-8 and Lot in Genesis 19:1-3.

questions.question: Hebrews 13:4 emphasizes the honor of which institution?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:4 declares that marriage is honorable in all and the marriage bed undefiled. This reinforces the biblical teaching on marriage's sanctity found in Genesis 2:24, Matthew 19:6, and Ephesians 5:25-33.

questions.question: What promise is cited in Hebrews 13:5 to encourage contentment?
options: I will provide all your needs
I will never leave thee, nor forsake thee
Seek first the kingdom of God
questions.correctAnswer: I will never leave thee, nor forsake thee
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:5 quotes God's promise to never leave nor forsake His people, encouraging contentment and trust. This promise is also found in Deuteronomy 31:6, Joshua 1:5, and reiterated in Matthew 28:20.

questions.question: Hebrews 13:6 says we may boldly say, 'The Lord is my helper,' so we will not fear what?
options: What man shall do unto me
questions.correctAnswer: What man shall do unto me
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:6 encourages boldness because the Lord is our helper, removing fear of human threats. This confidence is also expressed in Psalm 118:6, Isaiah 41:10, and Romans 8:31.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 13:7, whom should believers remember and imitate?
options: Those who have the rule over them
questions.correctAnswer: Those who have the rule over them
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:7 exhorts believers to remember and follow the faith of their leaders who have spoken God's word. This aligns with Paul’s instruction in 1 Thessalonians 5:12-13 and the example of elders in Acts 20:28.

questions.question: Hebrews 13:8 declares Jesus Christ is:
options: The same yesterday, today, and forever
questions.correctAnswer: The same yesterday, today, and forever
questions.explanation: This verse affirms the unchanging nature and eternal deity of Christ, consistent with Malachi 3:6, Isaiah 40:8, and Revelation 1:8, emphasizing His divine immutability.

questions.question: What warning does Hebrews 13:9 give regarding teachings?
options: Be not carried about with divers and strange doctrines
questions.correctAnswer: Be not carried about with divers and strange doctrines
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:9 warns against being swayed by various strange doctrines, highlighting the need for grace-based teaching. This resonates with Paul's warnings in Galatians 1:6-9 and 2 Timothy 4:3-4.

questions.question: Hebrews 13:10 speaks of an altar that belongs to whom?
questions.explanation: The verse contrasts the altar believers have with the one the Levitical priests serve, emphasizing Christ's superior priesthood, as also taught in Hebrews 7:11-27 and 10:19-22.

questions.question: Where did Jesus suffer to sanctify the people according to Hebrews 13:12?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:12 states Jesus suffered outside the city gate to sanctify people, fulfilling Old Testament sacrificial typology (Leviticus 16:27, Isaiah 53:12, and John 19:17).

questions.question: According to Hebrews 13:14, what kind of city do believers seek?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:14 teaches that Christians do not have a permanent earthly city but seek a heavenly one to come, echoing Hebrews 11:10, Philippians 3:20, and Revelation 21:2.

questions.question: What kind of sacrifice should believers offer continually according to Hebrews 13:15?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:15 exhorts believers to continually offer the sacrifice of praise to God, the fruit of lips giving thanks, consistent with Psalm 50:14, Psalm 107:22, and Romans 12:1.

questions.question: Hebrews 13:16 states God is pleased with sacrifices of doing what?
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:16 teaches that doing good and sharing with others are sacrifices pleasing to God, reflecting Proverbs 21:3, Isaiah 1:17, and Acts 20:35.

questions.question: Why should believers obey their leaders according to Hebrews 13:17?
options: Because they watch for your souls and must give account
questions.correctAnswer: Because they watch for your souls and must give account
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:17 emphasizes obedience to leaders who watch over souls and must give an account, resonating with 1 Thessalonians 5:12-13 and 1 Peter 5:2-3.

questions.question: Hebrews 13:20 identifies God as the one who:
options: Created the heavens and the earth
Brought again from the dead our Lord Jesus
questions.correctAnswer: Brought again from the dead our Lord Jesus
questions.explanation: Hebrews 13:20 calls God the God of peace who raised Jesus from the dead, affirming the resurrection central to Christian faith, consistent with Romans 6:4, 1 Corinthians 15:20, and Acts 2:24.
